briefdescription.para: constructs an empty task

detaileddescription.para: An empty task is not associated with any node in a taskflow.

briefdescription.para: constructs the task with the copy of the other task
replaces the contents with a copy of the other task
replaces the contents with a null pointer
compares if two tasks are associated with the same taskflow node

parameterdescription.para: the other task to compare with

simplesect.para: true if both tasks refer to the same node; false otherwise

briefdescription.para: compares if two tasks are not associated with the same taskflow node

parameterdescription.para: the other task to compare with

simplesect.para: true if they refer to different nodes; false otherwise

briefdescription.para: queries the name of the task

simplesect.para: the name of the task as a constant string reference

briefdescription.para: queries the number of successors of the task
queries the number of predecessors of the task
queries the number of strong dependencies of the task

detaileddescription.para:
the number of strong dependencies to this task
A strong dependency is a preceding link from one non-condition task to another task. For instance, task cond below has one strong dependency, while tasks yes and no each have one weak dependency.

simplesect.para: To understand how Taskflow schedule tasks under strong and weak dependencies, please refer to Conditional Tasking.

briefdescription.para: queries the number of weak dependencies of the task

detaileddescription.para:
the number of weak dependencies to this task
A weak dependency is a preceding link from one condition task to another task. For instance, task cond below has one strong dependency, while tasks yes and no each have one weak dependency.

simplesect.para: To understand how Taskflow schedule tasks under strong and weak dependencies, please refer to Conditional Tasking.

briefdescription.para: assigns a name to the task
assigns a callable

detaileddescription.para:
C
callable type
callable
callable to construct a task
*this
A tf::Task is polymorphic. Once created, you can reassign it to a different callable of a different task type using tf::Task::work. For example, the code below creates a static task and reworks it to a subflow task:

T
object type
object
a custom object that defines T::graph() method

The example below creates a module task from a taskflow:
To understand how Taskflow schedules a module task including how to create a schedulable graph, pleas refer to Create a Custom Composable Graph.

briefdescription.para: adds precedence links from this to other tasks

detaileddescription.para:
Ts
parameter pack
tasks
one or multiple tasks
*this
The example below creates a taskflow of two tasks, where task1 runs before task2.

briefdescription.para: adds precedence links from other tasks to this

detaileddescription.para:
Ts
parameter pack
tasks
one or multiple tasks
*this
The example below creates a taskflow of two tasks, where task1 runs before task2.

briefdescription.para: removes predecessor links from other tasks to this

detaileddescription.para:
Ts
parameter pack
tasks
one or multiple tasks
*this
This method removes the dependency links where the given tasks are predecessors of this task (i.e., tasks -> this). It ensures both sides of the dependency are updated to maintain graph consistency.

briefdescription.para: removes successor links from this to other tasks

detaileddescription.para:
Ts
parameter pack
tasks
one or multiple tasks
*this
This method removes the dependency links where this task is a predecessor of the given tasks (i.e., this -> tasks). It ensures both sides of the dependency are updated to maintain graph consistency.

simplesect.para: To know more about tf::Semaphore, please refer to Limit the Maximum Concurrency.

simplesect.para: To know more about tf::Semaphore, please refer to Limit the Maximum Concurrency.

briefdescription.para: makes the task acquire the given semaphore

briefdescription.para: makes the task acquire the given range of semaphores

simplesect.para: To know more about tf::Semaphore, please refer to Limit the Maximum Concurrency.

data
pointer to user data

The following example shows how to attach a user data to a task and retrieve it during the execution of the task.

briefdescription.para: resets the task handle to null

detaileddescription.para: Resetting a task will remove its associated taskflow node and make it an empty task.

briefdescription.para: resets the associated work to a placeholder
queries if the task handle is associated with a taskflow node

simplesect.para: true if the task is not associated with any taskflow node; otherwise false

detaileddescription.para: Note that an empty task is not equal to a placeholder task. A placeholder task is created from tf::Taskflow::placeholder and is associated with a taskflow node, but its work is not assigned yet.

briefdescription.para: queries if the task has a work assigned

simplesect.para: true if the task has a work assigned (not placeholder); otherwise false

briefdescription.para: applies an visitor callable to each successor of the task

detaileddescription.para:
V
a callable type (function, lambda, etc.) that accepts a tf::Task handle
visitor
visitor to apply to each subflow task
This method allows you to traverse and inspect successor tasks of this task. For instance, the code below iterates the two successors (task2 and task3) of task1.

briefdescription.para: applies an visitor callable to each predecessor of the task

detaileddescription.para:
V
a callable type (function, lambda, etc.) that accepts a tf::Task handle
visitor
visitor to apply to each predecessor task
This method allows you to traverse and inspect predecessor tasks of this task. For instance, the code below iterates the two predecessors (task2 and task3) of task1.

briefdescription.para: applies an visitor callable to each subflow task

detaileddescription.para:
V
a callable type (function, lambda, etc.) that accepts a tf::Task handle
visitor
visitor to apply to each subflow task
This method allows you to traverse and inspect tasks within a subflow. It only applies to a subflow task.

briefdescription.para: obtains a hash value of the underlying node

detaileddescription.para:
the hash value of the underlying node
The method returns std::hash on the underlying node pointer.

briefdescription.para: returns the task type

detaileddescription.para: A task can be one of the types defined in tf::TaskType and can be printed in a human-readable form using tf::to_string.

briefdescription.para: dumps the task through an output stream

detaileddescription.para: The method dumps the name and the type of this task through std::cout.

briefdescription.para: queries pointer to user data

detaileddescription.para:
C-styled pointer to the attached user data by tf::Task::data(void* data)
The following example shows how to attach a user data to a task and retrieve it during the execution of the task.

briefdescription.para: class to create a task handle over a taskflow node

detaileddescription.para: A task points to a node in a taskflow graph and provides a set of methods for users to access and modify attributes of the associated node, such as dependencies, callable, names, and so on. A task is a very lightweight object (i.e., it only stores a node pointer) and can be trivially copied around.

A task created from a taskflow can be one of the following types:
tf::TaskType::STATIC - Static Tasking
tf::TaskType::CONDITION - Conditional Tasking
tf::TaskType::RUNTIME - Runtime Tasking
tf::TaskType::SUBFLOW - Subflow Tasking
tf::TaskType::MODULE - Composable Tasking
A tf::Task is polymorphic. Once created, you can assign a different task type to it using tf::Task::work. For example, the code below creates a static task and then reworks it to a subflow task:

simplesect.para: tf::Task does not own the lifetime of the associated node. Accessing the attributes of the associated node after the taskflow has been destroyed can result in undefined behavior.
